newsitem.title: FRANCE: Terms of TMM-Daewoo deal unacceptable - commission.
newsitem.headline: Terms of TMM-Daewoo deal unacceptable - commission.

text.p: France's Privatisation Commission says the terms of a proposed sale by Lagardere Groupe of Thomson Multimedia (TMM) to Daewoo Electronics did not seem acceptable.

A copy of the commission's report on the privatisation of electronics group Thomson SA, which prompted the Finance Ministry earlier on Wednesday to suspend the proposed sale of Thomson to Lagardere, was obtained by Reuters.

"If in the short term Daewoo Electronics, in spite of a relatively weak capitalisation and high debt, brings to TMM certain financial resources...it is not clear that the medium term outcome is truly positive in that a sale of TMM would lead to the state's definitive renunciation of profit from first-rate resources in digital technology, flat screens, decoders, and components, although it contributed significant public funds from which the buyer would benefit," the report said.
It also said that while Daewoo had made social and investment commitments for TMM, it had no binding agreement to fulfil them with either the government or Lagardere.
And although Lagardere has declared itself as a "guarantor" of Daewoo's commitments, it has no means or leverage to ensure that the commitments are carried out.
"Under these circumstances, it is not possible to gauge the prospects for TMM once it has been transferred to Daewoo Electronics," the report said.
"For these reasons, the terms of the purchase of TMM by Daewoo Electronics do not seem to be acceptable."
The commission concluded that it could not "issue an opinion favourable to the acceptance of the offer (for Thomson) as it has been presented by Lagardere Groupe".
The government in October said it preferred Lagardere's bid for Thomson over a rival offer from Alcatel Alsthom but said it would comply with the independent Privatisation Commission's opinion.
